sections.title: FTP
sections.description: Hydra is a versatile and powerful password cracking tool commonly used in penetration testing to perform dictionary attacks or brute-force attacks against FTP servers.
sections.advancedUsage: Hydra can be used for more advanced tasks, such as attacking different services and protocols. Explore Hydra's documentation to learn more about its capabilities.

scriptExamples.title: FTP Brute-Force Attack
scriptExamples.description: Use Hydra to perform a brute-force attack on an FTP server with a custom username list and wordlist.

scriptExamples.title: FTP Dictionary Attack
scriptExamples.description: Perform a dictionary attack on an FTP server using Hydra.

usefulFlags.description: Enable verbose mode (show detailed output).
Specify the number of parallel threads to use.
Save results to a file.

sections.title: SSH (Secure Shell)
sections.description: Hydra is a versatile and powerful password cracking tool commonly used in penetration testing to perform dictionary attacks or brute-force attacks against SSH servers.
sections.advancedUsage: Hydra can be used for more advanced tasks, such as attacking different services and protocols. Explore Hydra's documentation to learn more about its capabilities.

scriptExamples.title: SSH Brute-Force Attack
scriptExamples.description: Use Hydra to perform a brute-force attack on an SSH server with a custom username list and wordlist.

scriptExamples.title: SSH Dictionary Attack
scriptExamples.description: Perform a dictionary attack on an SSH server using Hydra.

usefulFlags.description: Save results to a file.
Specify the number of parallel threads to use.

sections.title: HTTP
sections.description: Hydra can be used to perform HTTP login attacks, such as brute-forcing web application logins.
sections.advancedUsage: Hydra can be used for more advanced tasks, such as attacking different services and protocols. Explore Hydra's documentation to learn more about its capabilities.

scriptExamples.title: HTTP Login Brute-Force Attack
scriptExamples.description: Use Hydra to perform a brute-force attack on an HTTP login form with custom parameters.

usefulFlags.description: Save results to a file.
Specify the number of parallel threads to use.

sections.title: Everything
sections.description: Nmap is a powerful network scanning tool commonly used in penetration testing to discover open ports, services running on those ports, and gather information about network hosts.
sections.advancedUsage: Nmap provides various scan techniques and customization options for advanced network reconnaissance. Refer to Nmap's documentation to explore its full capabilities.

scriptExamples.title: Service Version Detection
scriptExamples.description: Use the '-sV' option to detect the version of services running on open ports.

scriptExamples.title: Operating System Detection
scriptExamples.description: Use the '-O' option to perform operating system detection.

scriptExamples.title: Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) Scanning
scriptExamples.description: Use the '--script vuln' option to scan for common vulnerabilities and exposures on open ports.

scriptExamples.title: List Available NSE Scripts
scriptExamples.description: To list available Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) scripts, use the '--script-help all' option.

usefulFlags.description: Specify specific ports to scan.
Enable OS detection, version detection, script scanning, and traceroute.
Save results to a file in normal format.
Set the timing template for the scan (e.g., -T4 for aggressive scan).
Perform a TCP SYN scan (Stealth Scan) to identify open ports.
Perform a UDP scan to identify open UDP ports.
Increase verbosity for more detailed output.
Perform traceroute to discover the route to the target.
Scan the top [number] most common ports.
Read target IP addresses from a file.
Exclude specified hosts from the scan.
Exclude hosts listed in a file from the scan.
Specify custom DNS servers for name resolution.
Set the time to wait between probes (e.g., 2s, 500ms).

sections.title: Overview
sections.description: Metasploit is a popular penetration testing and exploitation framework that provides a comprehensive suite of tools for assessing the security of networks, systems, and applications. It is widely used by security professionals to identify vulnerabilities and exploit them for testing and defensive purposes.
sections.advancedUsage: Metasploit offers advanced features, including payload creation, exploit development, post-exploitation modules, and extensive database integration. Users can customize and automate their tests using Metasploit's scripting and module framework.

scriptExamples.title: Basic Usage
scriptExamples.description: Launch the Metasploit console with 'msfconsole' to access various modules, exploits, payloads, and auxiliary tools.

scriptExamples.title: Exploit a Vulnerability
scriptExamples.description: Identify and exploit vulnerabilities using available modules and payloads.

scriptExamples.title: Payload Generation
scriptExamples.description: Generate custom payloads for remote access and control of compromised systems.

scriptExamples.title: Post-Exploitation
scriptExamples.description: Leverage post-exploitation modules for privilege escalation, lateral movement, and data exfiltration.

usefulFlags.description: Display the Metasploit Framework version.
Show the help message and list available options.
Run Metasploit in quiet mode, suppressing banner and startup information.
Accept the Metasploit End-User License Agreement (EULA) during startup.

sections.title: Resources
sections.description: Metasploit offers a wealth of resources for learning and mastering its capabilities:

sections.title: Overview
sections.description: Gobuster is a widely-used directory and file brute-forcing tool designed for web application penetration testing. It helps testers discover hidden files and directories on web servers by performing dictionary and brute-force attacks on URLs.
sections.advancedUsage: Gobuster supports various modes, including directory brute-forcing, file extensions enumeration, and DNS subdomain discovery. It provides extensive customization options for testing different aspects of a web application.

scriptExamples.title: Basic Directory Brute-Forcing
scriptExamples.description: Perform directory brute-forcing against a target URL using a specified wordlist.

scriptExamples.title: File Extension Enumeration
scriptExamples.description: Enumerate file extensions on a target URL using a specified wordlist.

scriptExamples.title: DNS Subdomain Discovery
scriptExamples.description: Discover subdomains of a domain using DNS brute-forcing.

usefulFlags.description: Specify the target URL or IP address.
Provide the path to the wordlist file containing directories or file names to test.
Set the number of concurrent threads to use for the scan.
Include extra file extensions when performing file extension enumeration.
Specify a comma-separated list of file extensions to test during file extension enumeration.
Specify the target domain for DNS subdomain discovery.
Save results to a specified output file.
Set the request timeout in seconds.
Set a custom User-Agent header for HTTP requests.
Specify cookies to include in HTTP requests.
Handle wildcard responses (common in web applications).
Ignore responses with different lengths.
Follow HTTP redirects.
Ignore SSL certificate errors.
Suppress 404 error messages.
Specify the number of threads to use.
Quiet mode (suppress banner and status messages).
Show help and available options.
Display Gobuster version.
Do not display progress status.
Specify a proxy for requests.
Use virtual host (HTTP/1.1 host header).
Quiet mode (suppress all output except results).
Expanded mode (show full URLs in output).
No progress (disable progress indicators).
Enumerate file extensions from a predefined list.
Append a trailing slash to each directory request.
Force uppercase and lowercase enumeration of directories.
Handle wildcard responses as valid entries.
Disable the use of system proxy settings.
Include all responses in the output (including 403 and 401 responses).
